answerKey.explanation: Release branches are cut from main (or trunk) to isolate stabilization work.
Stabilization prioritizes critical fixes, feature freezes, and release note prep.
Annotated, signed tags record release metadata and support audit trails.
Releases ship binaries, SBOMs, and changelogs; deleting history is never required.
Monitoring KPIs during rollout validates release health.
Backports target release branches, apply patches, and run focused tests.
Clear communication and postmortem windows ensure transparency.
Rollback strategies include redeploying prior tags, toggling flags, or shipping hotfixes.
Governance relies on signed commits/tags, restricted pushes, and secure artifact storage.
Issue templates with go/no-go gates standardize release execution.

keyPoints: Cut release branches early to isolate stabilization efforts.
Annotated, signed tags capture authoritative release metadata.
Freeze windows, targeted fixes, and release notes keep cadence predictable.
Backports are deliberate cherry-picks with testing and review gates.
Rollback plans and governance controls safeguard production releases.
